{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3492290,"name":"Enishan Eren Gücük ","username":"enishangck","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/a4c791/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-25T13:05:09.021Z","cooked":"

Hello, this year we are using mk4i L2 and neo engines, but when we rotate the robot around itself and move it forward, the robot slips. What could be the reason for this? Our robot does not have a problem with orientation. I can send a video if you want
@nstrike

This will always drift a little bit and dont bother tuning this until uou have your full robot built. To tune this you first tune the chassis discretization, and then the angular velocity coefficient. Both are functions in the SwerveDrive.

Really its not worth it most of the time just use a vision processor. It does get you over that little bump

The problem is not that it slides, the problem is that when I push the joystick forward, it slides to the right. First time we using pigeon 2 and we dont have this problem after we changed pigeon 2 to navX this happened

I know, again don’t bother trying to fix this yet bc the second you add or remove weight it will need to be tuned again.

Guides to tune this are here

docs.yagsl.com

Chassis Speed Discretization | YAGSL

More math...

docs.yagsl.com

Angular Velocity Compensation | YAGSL

Reasoning is here

Whitepaper: Swerve Drive Skew and Second Order Kinematics CD-Media: Papers
Team 449 made our first swerve drive a few months ago, and one of the first things we noticed is that when driving straight and spinning at the same time, the robot always skews in the direction of rotation. I’m sure many of you have also encountered this problem - if you’re wondering whether it’s happening because of an error in your code, the short answer is no. We spent a while trying to debug this issue, and through asking online we settled on the theory that since swerve constant translati…

And we no longer implement second order kinematics bc the difference was not significant enough

I posted some more info here

Share your tricks you used to improve your autos Programming
When trying to calculate your current pose, the pose estimator does an excellent job to a degree (again you can tune this but most teams dont). Teams should tune this if you’re using vision to help odometry. To tune vision it’s mostly guess and check on the stddevs with a scale depending on distance. Some teams experience better stability by filtering out all estimated poses X distance away and such. After that your odometry period can improve your data even further, but this is mostly limited …

Pugeon2’s have a higher sampling rate than the NavX so they are more accurate while doing this, you can compensate in code but it is a pain. This is why the pigeon 2 costs more than a navx. A CANandGyro should be able to do as well if not better than the Pigeon2
